pros: Strong Benefits are a plus.
cons: Too much turnover the past decade.

pros: A good amount of vacation and sick time. Met some great people.
cons: Your growth is completely limited to whether your supervisor/VP is willing to fight for your advancement. Management has no issue with you taking on higher level duties and going above and beyond, but do not expect any compensation except more work. Management has the discretion to advocate for your advancement, so if you do not have that support be prepared to stay exactly at the level you were hired into.

review_title: The university is ran like a business.
pros: The academics teaching the classes care for the students and want them to succeed.
cons: The administrators are there for a paycheck. They do not have the students' best interests in mind. In the last decade there have been 2 major layoffs and dissolutions of programs (always labelled as cost-cutting measures), stranding lecturers and students, while those in the highest levels, with the most pay, did not lose their positions. A latest move from 11 colleges to 6 did not coincide with the deans of those colleges losing their jobs. Instead, they were placed in other positions at the same pay. This means there are grossly overpaid assistant deans and provosts in schools while the departments are constantly asked to cut budgets and deny tenure/raises.

pros: Student success, opportunities from donors and endowments, the faculty of Myers are righteous. teaching is the most rewarding work. Watching a student achieve is the best reward for the effort required.
cons: Administration, politicians that believe they understand higher education better than faculty that have dedicated their lives to the profession.

pros: Uh???? I do not know of any

review_title: Budget and financial problems poor leadershi
pros: Very little to report that is positive. Employee moral continues to be low. Faculty leaving positions for other universities. Retention rate is poor with students transferring to other schools or accepting unprepared students not ready for rigor. Very little research is being conducted and poorly funded labs in all programs.
cons: Leadership at all levels continues to plague the campus. Academics are failing due to low student enrollment numbers. High volume of early high school students who attend then for high school credit then leave Akron for Kent State. Athletics continues to lose quality students and coaches. Staffing issues in all offices makes getting things done near impossible. Poor transparency of budget and finances and difficult to replace faculty who leave or retire. Too many adjunct part time instructors teaching earning very low, minimum wage pay while tuition prices rise for families

pros: Good pay, great people, good work environment

This saves driving time and gas money both of which are invaluable when you have children. The added perk of being able to attend courses at a substantial discount is the best pro in my opinion.
cons: The salary is less than average compared to other similar colleges and universities in the area. They are doing their due diligence to hire at the bottom of the pay ranges to not overspend on salaries as student enrollment continues to trend downward.

Staff employees who have picked up the slack of so many job losses are working hard and on the very low scale of the pay scale across the area.

review_title: Trying to improve, but a long way to go
pros: The new president isn't the spawn of Satan.  Wilson seems to care about students and wants to engage with him, in contrast with his predecessor who wouldn't even speak with students and who was hired to be a hatchet man.   There are still some staff who genuinely care about the students, and continue to do a great job even with little appreciation and no financial incentive.
cons:
Unequal salaries, nepotism and morale continue to be a problem .  They have supposedly instituted a freeze on raises - unless you have the right friends.  In that case you will be getting a huge raise even though most departments can't afford to buy office supplies.   Nobody wants to talk about it, and the administration is hiding it under all their back-clapping and self-congratulations over hiring a president who isn't a tool, but the university is still in dire financial straits and I wouldn't be surprised if there weren't more layoffs.

Powerful people continue to promote their unqualified friends, demoralizing those who are working hard and yet haven't seen an increase or promotion in years.  Jobs are filled by someone's buddy without ever being posted so other qualified individuals at least have a chance to apply.

pros: Great part time work, love the campus

pros: The University of Akron used to be a great place to work. The people used to be nice and the upper administration used to be supportive of academic endeavors. Not anymore.
cons:
The list of cons is endless. Let me mention just a few of them.
1. During the tenure of the previous president P. The focus shifted significantly from teaching the tuition - paying students and preparing them for real life to treating them as customers who pay the bills for completely useless projects like the football stadium. President P. Borrowed tens of millions to build a 60 mil stadium for an irrelevant football team that doesn't win one game a season. Ok perhaps one. In the mean time the professors don't have money to pay for photocopies for the tests or their class notes. 
2. Not even in the private sector you find 50 or more vice presidents with 6 figure salaries. All paid by students and their parents. And these kids get deeply in debt for these guys lavish lifestyles.
3. The academic atmosphere is tense. Competition for the meager resources between faculties is cutting-throat. 
4. The change of the name to Ohio Polytechnic University indicates a bad image of the name The University of Akron.  
5) Salaries are low even though they say the salaries are competitive with peer institutions.
6. There is too much PR in this place but little substance.
And the list goes on.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Akron, OH
pros: no good things at all
cons: very bad administrators and BOTs

pros: The new campus looks beautiful. The current administration has built more buildings than it can maintain.
cons: No leadership at any level of management (Board, CEO, COO, CFO, Deans, etc.) This university is just drifting with the current. There is no vision (even though they say they have Vision 2020...all lies). It does not fulfill its mission (lots of graduates do not find meaningful jobs and end up as retail associates or unemployed). Teaching is very difficult because all the resources are spent on the salaries and perks of "the members of the club" (that is the infinite number of vice presidents, associate vice presidents, assistant vice presidents, etc. etc. etc.) We had problems with not enough space, not enough lightning, the heating is minimal during the winter (I had students falling asleep in class because of the cold), the AC is usually off after 4PM during the summer after the administrators leave, etc. etc. etc. It is very difficult to do any kind of meaningful research. Minimal IT support, no technicians, etc. And I have heard that the university has recently started laying off staff.

review_title: It's only okay. I can only speak for my experience in Dining Services.
job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: I took this job as a "student assistant" aka fast food worker. The only good thing I have to say is that it's in a convenient location.
cons: Incompetent middle and upper management. Middle and upper management complain about labor costs while keeping the stores open when they only get 5 customers and hour. They say that they care about student putting their coursework first but they complain when you take time off to study for exams. They quickly chase competent managers out by giving them the work that the incompetent managers can't handle and then some. They are rude to the workers under them, fostering an adversarial relationship between them. They won't correct you when you do something wrong but instead complain to the people directly above you. They promise raises for people who stay on for a while but never follow through.

pros: Best thing about this position is that it pays your tuition plus a stipend to live on while completing your graduate studies.  You get the experience of teaching your knowledge to undergraduates, which helps you to better understand your field as well.
cons: You are definitely overworked.  They say you only work 20 hours per week, but in reality by the time you factor in grading, attending classes you TA, preparing for classes you have to teach, this position takes up a great deal of time and can add to the stressfulness of writing a thesis.  You have to be very good at time management to accomplish both.  Some professors act as if their TA is there to do all of their work for them and couldn't care less that the TA is also a student and does have other work to do as well.

review_title: Too many big ideas...not enough worker bees.
pros: Beautiful workplace, Excellent benefits (tuition remission, medical/vision/dental insurance, 22 vacation days)
cons: The University is extremely top heavy.  There are lots of new project ideas coming from the upper administrative offices - that must be completed immediately - but not enough actual 'hands-on' people to complete the task. We are over-tasked and underpaid.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: - High quality recreational center
cons:
-Low monthly payment: $1180(stipend) - $200 (class fees) - $100 insurance = $880 per month 
It's worth mentioning that the class fees is totally hidden. They don't give you any information prior to registration. Also, there is an unwritten law that you have to take 15 credit hours instead of 9 that immigration requires. In that case your net income would be even worse.

-Unclear contracts: Even though I signed a research assistant contract, I was forced to work as a teaching assistant EVERY semester

- Terrible insurance policy: Even though they charge around $100 a month for their insurance, they provide a very very bad insurance policy. It literally does not cover anything. The deductible is $500 and unless you are about to die, the insurance is practically useless.

pros: At the Taylor Institute for Direct Marketing, I am granted the freedom to perform my position to the best of my abilities. I really appreciate the guidance of my superiors who are very passionate about what they do and quick to defer to me when they feel I may have more knowledge of a topic. This is empowering and encouraging, as it contributes to me working my hardest to impress.
cons: There is often red tape that comes from outside the department and it makes things that could be streamlined take quite a while. It's frustrating, but it's a part of working in a large institution that is always concerned with the brand consistency as a whole. Definitely a major contributor to dealing with the same in the future.

review_title: There are some wonderful, dedicated people here, but as a state institution, there are some incompetent, uncaring people
pros: The University of Akron can be an exciting place to work -- one day is never like the next.  Working with students makes every day different.  I've always enjoyed working with people of different cultures and from different regions and the University of Akron has this diversity.  Being able to take classes is also a bonus.
cons: The biggest downside of working here is morale.  For me, there are two issues:  1 -- there are too people here who are just "watching the clock" and 2 -- recognition and monetary reward can only be offered to higher administration (since we must be equitable with state employees).  I would suggest that #2 is what leads people to become clock watchers.

pros: It is a great environment for talking to people, students, staff, and faculty. I get to speak with members of the community and get involved with my education. Campus is convenient and they are willing to work with my class schedule.
cons: University Administration has ignored the needs of staff. We are understaffed, have no custodial services, and have to do more work than one person can handle. Work is stressful and can be negative, as it is an ego game and entirely about making money. If you don't agree with the system that values business and money over education, they will try to push you out. They take no criticism.

pros: Flexibility, excellent departmental support, and good pay are all benefits of my current position.  I love teaching the students as well.  I have a lot of professional leeway in my classes, and I have been encouraged to apply when a full-time position has been open.
cons: There is a low level of job security in this and all part-time lecturer positions.  There is a lot of debate about this nationwide and at my institution.  I do not consider this a big issue, but I know some who do.  There are few benefits available.  For me, because of the hours I work, there is not a lot of interaction with my coworkers.  As an introvert, I do not see this as a big disadvantage.

review_title: Good place to work. Really some great improvements on the infrastructure (new buildings, etc).
pros: The people are all great. The student body is energetic. The salary will not be as much as you would get for a comparable job in the private sector, but the benefits and retirement plan are excellent. Contract professionals (full-time non union employees) also start out with 21 days vacation per year, as well as around 11 sick days vacation. Retirement plan choices are either the state retirement plan, or an alternate retirement plan, with the university contributing a 140% match for every dollar you put in, for up to 10% of your paycheck.
cons: The IT department could be more integrated. A lot of IT professionals are just left in "silo's", with no real connection to the IT department, which can make it difficult at times to get the correct hardware or software support.

review_title: On the surface, it looked promising, but there was a web of deceit that I could not have known about in advance.
pros: Campus is recently remodeled (within last 10 years) and facilities are fairly modern.  Akron is a pleasant community, easy to live in, especially for families.
cons: University culture, esp. from the administration, is corrupt and lacks integrity.  Business model encourages "adjunctification" of the faculty and protection of the administrative hierarchy.  Tenured faculty tend to be jealous, guarded, possessive and backstabbing.  Search committees are rife with partisanship and can be stacked with unqualified personnel (tangentially related to the department).  Romantic ties are problematic between administration and staff.

pros: The University of Akron is a great place to work.  The people are generally friendly, there is a good amount of diversity, there is a lot happening on-campus, the benefits are very good (free tuition, medical and dental insurance).  Akron is a great community to live in.
cons: Most positions are very underpaid compared to peer institutions.  Some upper administration can be apathetic and responds slowly.  HR is unhelpful and borderline rude. If you work really hard and accomplish a lot, there is no formal recognition and you work often goes unacknowledged by administration.

review_title: Grad Assistant = Easy job, but not enough $$$
pros: Being a graduate assistant at the University of Akron is an easy job, and most of the faculty are awesome.  The work is rewarding, and hours are flexible.
cons: The pay is definitely not great - barely livable.  I know the budget is low, but I really think the University would be better served with fewer, higher-quality GAs, who would earn higher salaries.  As it is, it seems that two half-competent people are often doing a job that could be done by one motivated and efficient worker, and each is earning only half a decent pay-check.

review_title: I received my PhD from the University of Akron and became employed there
pros: I had the privilege to work with Dr. Constance Carter Cooper, an amazing, forward thinking educator who was also perhaps the first female and certainly the first African American Dean in the College of Education.  She was a great mentor and encouraged  me to branch out and not to be afraid to pursue other opportunities within and outside of the university.
cons: As in all workplaces, politics abounded.  However, it taught me that you must learn how to live with politics and to know when to walk away.

pros: The director and manager of aquatics are amazing people. they are very fun and great leaders. there are a number of employees so if you cant make your shift there are plenty of options for people to cover you. Excellent training, never felt like i was undertrained. This place really prepared me for things outside of lifeguarding by building by work ethic and giving me confidence to be a leader
cons: sometimes it is cold in the ONAT and warm in the leisure pool... big deal though compared to the pros the cons are minimal.

job_title: Visiting Research Associate in Akron, OH
pros: The Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering departments are among the best in the USA. The labs were recently (partially) renovated.
cons: The University is in huge debt. They cut back wherever possible. If someone leaves he/she is not going to be replaced by anyone. It will be difficult to maintain the high ranking of the Uni. Postdoc salaries are low. Zero vacation for postdocs (if you accept a contract make sure that your official title is not postdoc!)

review_title: Great students to teach. Bad upper management.
pros: The students. They are the most hard working, eager to learn students anywhere.
cons:
Upper management is really bad. The department chairs and deans don't really understand how to manage. 
There is extreme sexism.
The union has cut salaries. Summer salaries disappeared thanks to them. Raises flat-lined at 2-3% thanks to them. Raises used to be as high as 15%.They need to leave.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros:
Working here as a student allowed me to get a sense for how the university (and large organizations in general) function.  This is great knowledge to have for business.  Additionally, the relationships you build while working between classes are doorways to further opportunity after graduation.

My boss was great at delegating, so he would make me "project manager" for things he needed to get done rather than micromanaging me.  This built skills that have come in handy at my professional job.  The work was a great facet of my education at UA.
cons: The pay isn't spectacular, but the experience makes up for it.

review_title: A great opportunity for students looking for paid tuition.
pros: The graduate assistant position allows you to get paid about ten dollars an hour and also obtain tuition remission. The assignments are  with professors who usually ask very little of their assistants and is generally a very pleasant job.
cons: The hours are flexible, the tuition remission is incredible, and the work is not very strenuous. The University does not monitor its graduate assistants all that well, so sometimes you are responsible for your work as well as others.

review_title: It was a rewarding experience made so by the abundance of friendly and capable co-workers and administrators.
pros: I enjoyed working there because they allowed you to grow in the job without micromanaging every task. If a mistake was made you were allowed to correct it and move forward.  I also attended school while working there and they were very respectful of my schedule.
cons: There are a lot of different cultures on a college campus and sometimes they clash.  You have to be respectful of other cultures and educate yourself as much as possible on how to handle yourself in these situations.

pros: I am a grad student there and this was the best decision ever made by me. I love this place. Professors are incredible, approachable, very knowledgeable. I study statistics and would love to take more time to study computer science. All my tuition were paid. Assistant ship was awesome.
cons: Maybe reputation is not great because it is not that expensive school. But a lot of kids from different backgrounds get to study here and that is good. Many talented people get to study.

pros: U of Akron is very forward thinking and have done a great job with the stadium and making the campus friendlier as far as a college campus goes - The pay is good and the faculty and staff are all very professional and courteous
cons: As with any college there can be too much politics but its not enough to offset everything that's going on campus and what's developing as far as architecture, funding and keeping different programs goes.

review_title: Great place to gain substantial research knowledge
job_title: Doctoral Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: The facilities are amazing. As a grad research assistant I get my own cubicle with my own two monitor computer. My boss, Dr. Leahy is an outstanding mentor, and a very easy going supervisor with a very laissez faire management approach.  You get direct research and program evaluation experience with local and state grants.
cons: Most jobs are soft money, meaning based on grants, so once the grant or the project are over, so are the positions.

pros: My advisor is very helpful and always provide me feedbacks with my research in timely manner. Senior phD students are always ready to help. A lot of collaboration with other departments (biology, engineering, physics and chemistry). As long as you research prior to pitch a project, my professor will give me permission to work on that project. Frequent Career fairs for undergrad and graduate students, helpful staff.
cons: Small number of graduate students enrolled last year and this year. Professors might not take you in their group even though the school administration already accepted you as a full time student.

review_title: It is a good starting point.
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Associate in Akron, OH
pros: College of Engineering is the fastest-growing engineering program in Ohio and fourth in the nation, according to a review of the nation's top 150 schools by the American Society for Engineering Education
cons: The work is not very strenuous. The University does not monitor its Post Doctoral Research Associates all that well, so sometimes you are responsible for your work as well as others.

pros: Your schedule is built around your class schedule, and the job is not mentally demanding.  Education is a priority and management is conscious of that.
cons: It's a temporary job, your experience will not look great on a resume.  It is not a desk job, so you can't really study or do homework while on the job.

job_title: Adjunct Professor With PhD in Akron, OH
pros: Loved my students, colleagues, and academic life.
cons: After earning several teaching awards, and holding a Ph.D. in my field, I was never promoted to full-time status nor given a salary that matched my skills and full-time work and commitment (even though I was slated as a "part-timer." U of Akron really abuses its adjunct faculty, many of whom should be full time faculty with full benefits and academic freedom. After 18 years in the academy and over a decade at U of A, I could no longer tolerate such disrespect and abuse.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: Polymers and engineering programs, possibly still the psyc department and the law school, maybe the MBA program... Also the men's soccer team, track and field, rifle and maybe golf and depending on the year men's basketball.
cons:
If you are in the social sciences, good luck, they care absolutely nothing about you. They have demonstrated the little dedication they have to the social sciences by merging three departments (Political Science, Pub. Adm. and Economics into 1 super department). Why because the upper administration could not provide adequate adjustments to retiring professors, moving professors or problem professors. The MPA program lost it's accreditation while the PhD Pub Adm program closed its doors to new students due to its inability to maintain bright professors.  

While a few key people are trying to make a change in terms of diversity and tolerance there is not enough action being taken, one big un-addressed issue by the administrators is its archaic Discrimination Clause. Basically certain groups can still be discriminated against, take a guess!

Athletics, a joke! Like I said minus those programs that actually have done decent, let alone kicked butt nationally, the rest is a sad stuck vision on growing the non-olympic programs (aka football). I think Division II football teams might get way more attention than the UA's football team. Instead of building on success they are obsessed with re-gluing the broken pieces of the football program.

job_title: Athletics Development Student Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: Great networking and fundraising practicality. Helpful staff as in most of the higher learning environment. Very flexible boss and great institution to work for.
cons: No placement after internship was finished. School cut 214 positions so work will be scarce there for years to come. Athletics work for sometime 60hrs in a week and are not compensated for it.

pros: The university location in Akron, OH is a beautiful and semiconductor location. Additionally, graduate assistants earn tuition waivers which have been financial life savers for myself and my colleagues.
cons: Unfortunately the current status is that there is a lot of transitioning leadership occurring. There is an obvious disjoint between the administration and the populations they serve and community they represent.

pros: Payment was easy to arrange with the billing office. The staff was easy to work with. As a contract employee, dates were set in advance.
cons: The payroll system is a little hard to maneuver if you have never worked with the university before and the instructions for setting up an account are not intuitive. You receive NO paychecks or statements.

review_title: Overall, good. Wages set into specific job classes. Not much of a 'work your way up' system on my end of things.
pros: Good environment for the most part. Some freedom during the summer is nice (full time during summers too).
cons: Wages could be higher. Taxes, medical, and retirement take 40% of take-home. Makes for a low cash flow living but with med benefits (which can still be too difficult to pay for out of pocket). Kind of a toss-up.

pros: Very little supervision from the higher ups so we are free to design a course we like, as long as it meets the criteria laid out by the college.
cons: Isolated. And no guarantee from semester to semester that you'll still have a job. Even if you're assigned classes and they fill enough to run, they may be snatched away from you at the last minute and you'll be out of a job. If you can do anything else, ANYTHING ELSE, do it. This is not a place to build a career.

pros: Your research can go as far as your advisor. Find one that is exactly the research you are interested in, or find one that is willing to work with you. No need to choose an advisor that you dont feel excited to visit, otherwise your research will be grueling
cons: Find the dynamic of your lab you are interested in, some like to work alone and not share information or help you learn. Others are open to helping and working together. find the one that fits your style!

pros: They are very understanding and are willing to work around a student's class schedule. My bosses have always been very kind to me.
cons: The only downside I can think of is the pay being only minimum wage, but I honestly can't expect a higher pay than that considering how easy my job is.

pros: Flexible, coworkers usually have a good personality. They're usually able to work with you .
cons: The athletics department is very understaffed and highly depends on their GA's. There are a lot of internal management problems and the school's profits are on the decline.

review_title: Student Supervisor at the University of Akron's Student Recreation and Wellness Center
pros: Able to maintain a work, school, and social life balance. Management has to be understanding of school schedule since it is apart of the University.
cons: Working with multiple students means that management is focusing on making everyone's schedule convenient for school. Some shifts may not be ideal times of the day.

pros: I enjoyed working there because they allowed you to grow in the job without micromanaging every task. If a mistake was made you were allowed to correct it and move forward. I also attended school while working there and they were very respectful of my schedule.
cons: Issues with the budget and upper management poor decisions created a unproductive work environment for some people.

review_title: I was very busy but overall I enjoyed my position.
job_title: Graduate Researcher/Teaching Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
-Meeting interesting people
-There is a good Rec Center on Campus as well as good options for good
-One can work all hours
cons:
-As a student employee I had very little free time 
-It was unorganized which lead to a lot of confusion for the employees
-The university was constantly under funding departments, cutting out department to save money, yet able to spend huge quantity of money on expanding the campus.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in North Canton, OH
pros: Faculty and staff are great people to work with and The University, as of this writing, offers great benefits including fee remission.
cons: Very little direction and leadership from upper management as well as limited to no clear policies and procedures.

pros: Winter Break off with pay.  Most holidays off as well.  Tuition Remission for you and family.
cons: Part of a Union so you are subject to lay offs as well as a set pay rate regardless of hard work.

pros: Friendly coworkers, very good at scheduling around class schedules and allowed homework to be done when all current tasks were completed.
cons: Not enough workers to keep up with heavy scheduling seasons, at times felt under appreciated, poor pay and angry students made the job feel taxing.

pros: Started off great.  Access to many educational resources all over campus.  Tuition deferment. Made lifelong friendships with some amazing, brilliant, way too patient co-workers.
cons:
From when I started there in 2005 until the end of 2010, I loved my job there.  However, when they implemented a big restructuring/reorganization in 2011 in my department, it went downhill fast.  The morale in my department and overall attitude on campus has become so tense to the point that I could no longer tolerate being near these people.  Campus has now become nothing more than a battle ground of class warfare between faculty versus staff.  It is a great employer if you're a tenured faculty member, but it's a horrible place to work if you're a staff member, a contract professional, or PT faculty member.  They keep chipping away at the benefits and don't give raises or advancement opportunities to staff, but faculty get raises, promotions, extra benefits that staff don't get, and are treated like gods - so they, in turn, feel entitled to treat all their subordinates with a ridiculous amount of disrespect, even though many staff has just as much (if not more!) education than their so-called "superiors."  Staff are the backbone of that university and keep that place running--they are dedicated and hard-working, yet are underpaid and unappreciated, especially in my department

Managers there are extremely immature and selfish, and are neither sympathetic or empathetic to others outside of their "circle."  Most are opportunist ladder-climbers who were only nice to those whom they felt could advance their careers.  Since I was nothing more to them than their slave, they certainly treated me as such!  They demand the utmost respect from staff, but don't give any respect in return to staff.  I was yelled at repeatedly for things that were out of my control; had my intelligence insulted publicly at a meeting; had the phone hung up on me when my boss was mad that something didn't go her way despite how hard I tried to fix a bad situation that SHE created; witnessed my supervisor having many "tantrums" where she would stomp around the office suite slamming doors, pound her fist on the conference table, and use such vile swearing language; and they would often ignore meetings that I would arrange (not show up or call ahead of time to let me know they wouldn't be there while I sat in the empty conference room waiting for them!), but they would yell at me if I was one minute late to one of their meetings (even if it was because I was busy assisting a student!).  Respect was obviously not a 2-way street in their eyes!

It's plainly obvious that some of these faculty have severe mental health issues, but everyone in my circle was terrified to ever defend themselves whenever they were unjustly attacked because they were worried about losing their jobs.  I can understand that the faculty have a lot on their plate too (although the faculty in my department don't even deal directly with the students anymore, so who knows what they're up to all day in their offices behind closed doors--that is, if they ever even show up for work!  Most would come in late and leave early, and/or take long lunch breaks, and never put in a 40 hour work week like the staff, which is extremely unfair!).  No matter how bad of a day you're having, there is NO justification for taking your anger out on someone else.  I would never dream of treating even an animal the way they treated their staff!!  

There were so many brilliant staff that aren't given duties or projects that coincided with their skills and abilities.  Such a waste!  It was always the same faculty members on all the important committees (you'd rarely see a staff member on a search committee).  Managers are jealous, insecure control freaks who feel threatened by anyone below them with a brain, so they either degrade them until they quit or lose all of their self-worth.  Faculty make snap decisions all the time but would often not communicate them (the running joke is that we didn't know a new rule existed until we got yelled at for breaking it!), but staff have no say in any decisions made.  They are often vindictive, conniving, tyrannical, abuse their power, and burn bridges with their nasty behavior.  They are often disorganized and blame everyone but themselves for their bad decisions.  I was never praised for all the good and hard work I did, but you can bet I was crucified for the rare mistake I would make.  When my boss had an error that she had clearly made (and couldn't pawn off on someone else) pointed out to her, she merely giggled and said "my bad!" but if I made a mistake, she would brow-beat me and say how it was "unacceptable" and "made the department look bad."  Likewise, I was never thanked for any of their huge mistakes that I caught and fixed, or given any credit for all the good ideas I had that they implemented--they shamelessly took all the credit themselves!  They behaved just liked schoolyard bullies!  I often felt like I was adult and they were the children, and yet the children were in charge and I could never discipline them no matter how much they misbehaved!! You just couldn't do anything right.  I would often go home crying every night and had high blood pressure, insomnia, and anxiety attacks.  After almost 9 years there (I had planned to be a "lifer" at that employer) I eventually had to quit at the advice of my doctor who said that if I stayed in such a high-risk environment any longer, I could risk having a heart attack or stroke, and UA is certainly not worth dying for!!

review_title: A great place to go to school and to work!
pros: I love working on campus because everything's close, the people are always friendly and hours work around your school schedule.
cons: Night shifts aren't the best but not that bad and I wish everyone wasn't so strict.

review_title: A place dedicated to serving the student
pros: UA provides great technology for students and instructors.   From the instructor's prospective, the students are eager, the administration is supportive and the atmosphere is friendly.  Best of all I get the privilege of working with some really smart people.
cons: I would like to see a full time position, at my campus, in my field

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
Great polymer school. medium size but decent campus. Great Rec Center-one of the best in nation. 

Closeby Cuyahoga Valley National Park  is an added benefits if you are nature lover.
cons:
Safety  of the certain parts of the neighborhood. Avoid those areas in general.
Not a big city so you don't expect a lot from this city.
Graduate Assistantship is average.

pros:
*GREAT benefits (good healthcare at a low cost, free dental, generous retirement savings plan)
*Relaxed work environment
*Free tuition for employees 
*Gym on campus has special rate for employees
*Worked with many nice, smart, and talented people
*Perfect work/life balance
cons:
*Pay can be on the low side
*New President of the University eliminated many positions

review_title: Great experience as teaching assistant for psychology department
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
great training program that was based on solid research and gave me confidence
good colleagues
helpful supervisor
weekly meetings with other psych TA's to discuss problems, teaching techniques, what's working, what we're struggling with
cons:
most students seemed really unmotivated
don't think the students live up to their potential which makes teaching them hard
not the best pay

review_title: A good place to earn a graduate degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: The University of Akron has nice real people and culture with newer buildings,  city is building and has nice places to eat and have fun. Very affordable housing too.
cons: The pay is less than other universities. The research pace in many departments can be slow compared to other institutions.

job_title: Ph D Graduate Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
Good pay for a PhD graduate student, taking into a account how cheap the Akron are is. 
Nice people, great place if you are into polymers.
cons: You have to renew your graduate contract now and then and sometimes the office does not do it on time and you end up without one month's salary all the sudden.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: The research atmosphere here is very good, good facilities, good professors, and good students. The polymer program is one of the best program in the US
cons: The salary is relatively low for old graduate, but the salary of the new graduate was increased. The polymer program is under reconstruction, many old renowned professors are going to retire soon

pros: Flexible, interactive workplace. I've enjoyed working with the members of the departement and they can ultimately help you network across the rest of campus.
cons: We're short staffed so I find myself working most shifts alone which can be stressful at times. Students are always looking for employment so it,d be nice if they hired more people.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: Nice environment, good facilities and laboratories. Good Gym and dining services. Transportation and residence halls are good. Staffs are very nice and helpful.
cons: Some Professors of college of engineering do not  have enough knowledge of what they are teaching. They are rude and not caring about if the students learn. The exams are ridiculous.

pros: Working as a GA allows for paid tuition, a biweekly stipend, nice coworkers, and experience that looks good on a resume.
cons: There are not many cons, except sometimes putting GA work ahead of classwork. It is a good experience that I highly recommend.

job_title: ECE Graduate Teaching Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
Pays almost the highest in the university for graduate students.
Get to learn a lot of stuff as a teaching assistant
cons: Sometimes there can be a ton load of work especially if your class has a test coming up.

review_title: Student assistant College of Engineering DTS
pros: Flexible schedule, easy to adapt to environment, entry level offering a lot of experience! This is a very good on-campus job for quick cash
cons: Since this is a considered a non profit organization the non full time employees get Little pay, and are limited to less than 30 hours a week

review_title: A great place to work if you don't need the money.
pros: People most of the people are great and it is an enjoyable experience to come to work everyday.
cons: Working for wages well below the poverty level makes it hard to survive.

job_title: Statistics Graduate Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
I get free tuition and a little bit of spending money… almost enough to cover my eating expenses.   Also, the professors in my area are pretty great.  

Don’t pay attention to my ratings as I am not pursuing a career at the university.
cons:
funding cuts
more funding cuts...
and even more funding cuts

pros:
nice physical surrondings
Academic environment
easy commute
good parking
salary OK
athletic and other events
near downtown
strong community support
cons:
there is some amount of crime in the surronding neighborhoods
the state of ohio provides limited support for higher education

job_title: Student Assistant Dining Administrative in Akron, OH
pros: Flexibility of hours, great co-workers, decent pay for a student, great opportunities, opportunity for advancement
cons: Pay to low to live on own, can no longer work here if not a student at the university

pros:
Tuition reimbursement (if you have the time to take classes)
Some nice coworkers
cons: Too long to list - clueless management, ridiculous workload, total lack of communication, people elevated way beyond their level of competence, salary inequity that is so lopsided it should be criminal, administration and faculty who care nothing about students,lack of advancement (you'll get the work load but not the paycheck), gross financial mismanagement.  You'd be a fool to take a job here.

pros: I can do homework at work. Low pressure environment while getting experience in my field.
cons: Nothing to do most days. I get bored easily. Time from application submission to job offer was like 3 days, so I had to make a quick decision.

pros: Excellent experience, made me a more well rounded open individual while enhancing my leadership skills. fair wage as well as living environment provided
cons: Truly no cons to this experience. I would highly recommend this to students attending the university. not just for the money, but for the social experience it provides.

pros: Pros- "Great opportunities, great work environment, learning opportunities, qualified and helpful professors, forward thinking.best technologies are available and good graduate assistantships.
cons: lot of competition, you might end up working on projects on your own sometimes, it is sometimes difficult to coordinate between departments, less pay and no assistantships in summers.

review_title: Very Good Job With Awesome Bosses
job_title: Audio Visual Services Student Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: The guys in AVS are amazing and very reasonable with scheduling for classes, have had an continue to have a good job with all the AVS staff. Allows me to do HW while working.
cons: None that I can think of

review_title: Good university but the department management need to be improved
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: The working environment is good, all staffs and faculties are nice and friendly.
cons: May lack of financial support and several old staffs in our department have been laid off or left.

job_title: Special Events Parking Lot Monitor in Akron, OH
pros:
Parking Dept.- Special Events
current student working here, but not bad got a raise with min. wage law, then another on top of that for working there 4 semesters.
cons:
Constantly exposed to elements such as wind,rain,snow,heat,cold etc...
taking money in exchange for tickets, balancing money with tickets

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: Professors are willing to help you when you need it, show that they care about your academic experience and career after graduating.
cons: Can sometimes feel like you basically are the teacher while getting paid as a graduate student. Grading can become tedious, menial and repetitive.

pros: Campus is nice, you have the opportunity to work a flexible schedule, being a graduate student you get paid to learn and complete your education
cons: The University is currently struggling financially and is having to cut programs and jobs and is trying to reinvent itself.

pros: The supervisors are very helpful to teach you how things should be done. Nice working environment. Great place to gather job experience.
cons:
Low payment policy
New President terminated so many GA and staffs.

pros: It has a Good engineering department. Great area of the country in which to live. Some Good facilities - some extremely outdated.
cons: Extreme campus wide discrimination. Stay away if you are not a perfectly healthy white male. Low morale. Management has no concern for employees.

review_title: Working is good but Ohio is always rainy or snowy
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Akron, OH
pros:
Friendly Environment
Caring staff
Gym is best part of University
EJ Thomas hall is fun
Movies are good
cons:
Weather
you can not get out of your office for at least 6 months
City is small and hard to find fun stuff to do

review_title: An engineer and technician in the field of Civil Engineering and GIS
pros: I never give up and work very hard. Independence and creativity are the other strength that you can depend on.
cons: I am still developing my leadership style through formal and informal education.

pros:
Very flexible
Made my own schedule
Did homework when there were no projects to do
cons: The department down the hall from me was frustrating. They were not accommodating to students and if you didn't do things their way, they wouldn't accept it

review_title: Departments are highly segregated and make servicing students hard.
pros: Some of the staff go above and beyond. Great chance to meet new people and impact lives
cons: Bad budgeting, old software, minimum wage.

review_title: It has been a great place to work
pros: This is a job that really means something. Working with students is very rewarding
cons: UA s reputation has taken some negative hits in the last few years but hopefully that is changing

pros: Plenty of on-campus jobs for students, management is great, very flexible scheduling, direct deposit.
cons: 12 credit minimum to remain employed, lots of paperwork to go through during hiring, payroll can be slow at adding you to system.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Akron, OH
pros: The department is wonderful.  People are supportive and understanding.
cons: The workload is very high, pay is terrible.

pros: New staff, emerging city and new buildings
cons: Not enough scholarships for emerging students in different accredited degrees

pros: I got a lot of great experience working with Data Entry programs, meeting new people, and speaking in front of large groups.
cons: Pay could have been better, but it was a student job, so...

review_title: Not what I had in mind
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Akron, OH
pros:
Mid-size city, everything is nearby.
Big cities are very close.
cons:
Small University, big bureaucracy.
Not the academic level I was expecting

job_title: Market Research Analyst and Marketing/SAP CRM Consultant in Akron, OH
pros:
Getting the financial support from companies who looking for the CRM consultant 
The campus project used latest information and study to reach a high performance
cons: lack of coordination and time management

pros: Great city, low cost of living, great students.
cons: Leadership espouses the value of academic advising in student success but their enacted values indicate that they don't value retaining talented advisors and want to outsource advising to private contractors.

review_title: The University of Akron, Akron, Ohio
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Akron, OH
pros: It is good university, it provides a lot of experience and make me very commanding on my field.
cons: All things are good but I want the company skills rather than university's skill.
